17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - Cereal, meat, milk, gravy or potatoes, bread, fruit or syrup.

Dinner - Meat, potatoes, bread, vegetables when available, pie pudding or dried stewed fruit.

Supper - Soup, meat or fish or fowl, vegetables, bread cake, dried stewed fruit or home canned, breakfast milk.

Time of year did not make much difference as the men did heavy work. Bread and milk was a warm weather supper.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

My father, W.H. Sketchley moved from Okla W.B. to the Quill Lake district Sept. 1902, hauling our possessions overland from Yorkton some 125 miles. Ours was the first family, my age 12 years. It was the fall of 1904 that the first construction trains were operated through Quill Lake and some provisions could be obtained through this medium. Until that time everything was hauled from Yorkton or Sheho. The winter months were "freighting time." The settler bought in quantities and at the close of winter freighting had supplies to last pretty well through the following summer. The plentifulness of prairie chickens, rabbit, ducks solved the fresh meat problem.

It was more economical to buy in quantity and many people kept up the practice, and many were the mail orders mostly to Eaton's for those articles which could be kept for long periods. I observed this practice for a good many years after becoming a housewife.

My husband came to the district through freighting grocery supplies for the rail roaders. 1904. He farmed with oxen at first.
My husband came to the district through farming grocery supplies after the mail arrived in 1904. He farmed with crops at first.

My father, Mr. H. Smithley moved from Okla. No. S. to the Quill Lake district Sept. 1903, hauling our possessions overland from Yorkton some 125 miles. Our was the first family, my age 19 years. We were the fall of 1904 that the first construction train was operated through Quill Lake and some farms were started from Yorkton to Skaha. The winter months were fraught with many difficulties which could be helped for long periods. I believe this freedom for a good many years after becoming a housewife.
